notes:
Company email (July 2015)
"I can assure you that Soleado is a vegan wine."

Company email (June 2015):
"I can assure you that Aussie Rosé Flamingo is a completely vegan wine."

Note from Louise (May 2014)

"I have information about a vegan wine. It’s a red wine called Chill Out Mountains Malbec Organic. On their Swedish homepage you can read: “Chill Out Mountains Malbec is a good choice for strict vegetarians as no animal products have been used in the processing/filtration of the product .”" [http://www.altia.se/se/HEM/]

Company email (March 2017)

"Para el proceso de clarificación usamos proteína Vegetal (de Papa) y Bentonita (Arcilla montmorillonita) y para filtrar utilizamos tierras de diatomeas... La respuesta anterior aplica para todos los productos de VLR en vinos blancos, espumantes y tintos varietales. Para vinos tintos reserva y/o superiores usamos albumina"

[Google translation: "For the process of clarification we use vegetable protein (from potato) and Bentonite (clay montmorillonite) and to filter we use diatomaceous earth... The above answer applies to all VLR products in white, sparkling and varietal red wines. For reserve red wines and / or higher we use albumin."]
address: Edificio Paseo Las Palmas, Coyancura 2283, Of. 602

notes:
Company email (January 2017)

"We are not certified yet as a Vegan Winery, but we act as one. We do not use any milk, egg and honey derived and also we do not use any gelatines or isinglass.
Let's say for the Barolos from the last released vintage our wines are vegan, and for the Barbera from 2015 vintage. Also our wines are manufactured/bottled only here in La Morra at the winery."

Company email (February 2017)

"All our white wines are suitable for vegans while the red wines are not."

Company email (February 2014):
"The reds all appear to have been fined with egg white and the whites have been made with the use of milk products.
 
The only wine that does not have any additive on the label is the Whitefields Pinot Grigio. I have cc’d our wine maker Joel Pizzini who may elaborate on my reply.
 
La Cantina wines in the King Valley say they do not use preservatives but I am not sure of their wine additives."

doubled_by: CR, Masada, defiant4good, AngelA, Benji, Shelley, Carolyne, Joy, Emma, Kristy
notes:
Barnivore note: the Casella family are pro-hunting and one brother owns an ammunition factory. http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/local-hunters-keen-to-begin-national-parks-trial-20140118-311l5.html

Company email (November 2016) asking about Sangria:
"...you will be thrilled to know all our red varieties are vegan friendly. Our white varieties on the other hand are not as we use animal products (gelatine) in the fining, although all the gelatine is removed during filtering before bottling."

Company email (August 2016):
"We’re pleased to let you know that all our red varieties are vegan friendly.
 
"Our white varieties on the other hand are not vegan friendly as we use animal products (gelatine) in the fining process, although all the gelatine is removed during filtering before bottling."

Company email (June 2016):
"The Mallee Point Pink Moscato is fined with Gelatin before bottling, which is an animal product. All of our YT white wines would be the same as above, but [yellow tail] red wines are not fined before bottling and hence would be suitable for you."

Company email (December 2015):
"We're pleased to let you know that all our red varieties are vegan friendly. 

"Our white varieties on the other hand are not vegan friendly as we use animal products (gelatine) in the fining process, although all the gelatine is removed during filtering before bottling."

Company email (December 2011):
"Thanks for your inquiry, I am pleased to tell you that Mallee Point reds are vegan friendly."

Company email (March 2010):
Listed all red wines

Updates (August 2009):
"[yellow tail] Rosé is not vegan friendly as gelatine is use in fining the white wine component of the wine."

Company email:
"[yellow tail] red wines are vegan and don't contain any animal product at all. The residual sugar or RS in our wine is derived from grape juice concentrate which we produce at our winery complex."

Here's something cool: "http://discoveryellowtail.com has a nutritional info tab that actually says if the wine is vegan friendly or not! (Thanks Masada!)"

Company email:
"All of our [yellow tail] red wines are vegan - they contain absolutely no animal byproducts, nor are animal byproducts used during any phase of the winemaking process. Our [yellow tail] white wines, however, do use gelatin as part of the finishing/clarification process. Due to the incredible amount of vegan inquiries we receive, we will be posting this information on our website shortly."

doubled_by: Belinda, Andrew, Sara, Danielle, Sari, Chamindri, Anthony, Leigh, Company, Karla

notes:
Company email (February 2016)

"Nous vous remercions de l’intérêt que vous portez à nos vins et tenions à vous informer que le château Mas Neuf Rhône Paradox Blanc ne présente aucun produit d’origine animale et convient donc au mode de vie vegan."

[Google Translate: "Thank you for your interest in our wines and wanted to inform you that the Mas Neuf Rhône Paradox White Castle has no animal products and is therefore suitable to the vegan lifestyle."]

Company email (April 2017) re Whispering Angel Rose

"We can confirm that our Whispering Angel is vegan friendly as no animal products are used to make it nor during the filtration. It is produced in our cellars, therefore the processing system is the same."

Company email (March 2016)

"All our Red wines is free of any animal products, although it’s not certified by a Vegan society, we don’t use any gelatine or any other animal products in the making of the wine."

Company email (February 2017)

"These [wines] are also Vegan friendly from 2016 onwards."

Note from Madge (December 2014):
"Company representative gave me a list of their vegan wines, and they seem to have a lot of them!
Here's a list:
De Bortoli Sacred Hill Chardonnay (2014 Vintage)
De Bortoli Windy Peak range
De Bortoli Yarra Valley range
De Bortoli Bella Riva range
De Bortoli Deen range (white wines only)
De Bortoli Gulf Station range
De Bortoli Riorret range
De Bortoli Melbra range"

Company email (December 2014): re: Sacred Hill Traminer Riesling
"To answer your question about the wine being suitable for vegan consumption, unfortunately the short answer is no. Gelatine has been used in the processing of the 2014 vintage, and isinglass and milk have been used along with the gelatine in the previous vintages.
The only place the wine is manufactured or bottled is at our head winery in Bilbul NSW."

Company email (February 2014): re: 2011 Yarra Valley Pinot Noir
"The wine maker has confirmed that this wine is suitable for Vegans:

Company email (February 2014):
"We do on occasions have wines that use gelatine, isinglass,  etc as processing aids, its entirely up  to the winemaker and can change vintage to vintage depending on the conditions of that particular harvest. We do have wines that are suitable for vegans though we make no such claims.
Examples:
2013 Deen De Bortoli Chardonnay
2013 Windy Peak Shiraz 
2013 Deen De Bortoli Sauvignon Blanc 
2013 Yarra Valley Estate Grown Pinot Noir"

Company email (May 2012):
"I confirm you that Distilleria Bottega products (Wine, grappas and liquors - except for milk cream like Fior di latte or Latte Macchiato or other liquors that specifically contain animal ingredients well descripted in ingredients list) don't contain any animal ingredients or additives (expecially those used in wine filtration)."

Company email (June 2016)

"We produce 100% of our wine right here in Little Sands, PEI. We do not use fish, meat, eggs or milk products. We do use honey in  our Blackberry Mead and to sweeten some fruit wines because honey is a  local product and cane sugar is not local."

Company email (November 2016)

"It is important to note that we will occasionally use casein or egg white if needed when finishing our wines, so we will strive to keep this list updated as new vintages are released. The list below includes every current and future release vegan-friendly wine. Hidden Bench wines found in restaurants will almost always be the “Bistro” series, and can be trusted to be vegan.
 
All the wines below are vegan:
 
2013 Estate Pinot Noir – Available at the LCBO
2013 Bistro Pinot Noir
2014 Bistro Chardonnay
2014 Estate Chardonnay
2013 Estate Chardonnay – Available at the LCBO
2014 Bistro Riesling
2014 Estate Riesling
2013 Roman`s Block Riesling
2014 Bistro Rose
2013 Bistro Red
2011 Terroir Cache
2011 La Brunante
2012 Terroir Cache"

"I wrote to them and they really didn't know what makes a wine vegan. (if using a little egg to filter, it doesn't make a wine not suitable for vegans.......)
 
This two wine is really vegan from them:
 
Napbor
Örökké"

Company email (March 2015):
"We did not use any animal parts during production, so it is 100% vegetarian."

notes:
Company email:

According to our winemaker you will have to give the white wines a skip. Avoid the Goats do Roam and the Pinotage, as we buy in some wine for these, and am not sure what they have done to it. All the other red wines are safe for you to enjoy.

Company email (September 2014):

"I am afraid to let you know that there are some wines that we have used products containing eggs to filter them, though this is a very expensive treatment. But because of this reason and because we are aware of vegan consumers we are starting to stop this use of products, as you may know some of our wines are from past vintages and have been already bottled so those are the wines my colleague Juan Ignacio was talking about. For  next vintages you will be able to try our wines because they will be with no traces of this kind of products!

Our Vegan Friendly Wines arriving into Dan Murphy’s by the end of this year:

Zuccardi Serie A Bonarda 2013
Zuccardi Serie A Malbec 2013
Zuccardi Serie A Chardonnay Viognier 2013"

Note from Danielle (June 2014):
"Unfortunately I didn't see the "this product has been made with the aid of egg..." until after I'd purchased it. This is the 2011 Serie A Malbec." [If you would like to see a copy of the picture of the label, please email contact@barnivore.com.]

Company email (February 2014):
"All our wines nowadays are vegan friendly. We don't use any animal products or derivatives."

Company email (January 2011)
"Our wines DO NOT contain any animal ingredients or animal products.
For filtration, we use mechanic procedures and mineral materials (like bentonite) sometimes"

Company email (November 2010)
"Ian, our Wines are 100% vegan-friendly"

Company email (October 2010)
"We only use bentonite (it's a mineral) for fining our wines. Our wines are vegan."

Company email (November 2016)
"This is the list of wines vegan friendly

Santa Julia Organica
Santa Julia Reserva

"All these wines doesn´t  contain any animal ingredients (such as milk, eggs, honey, etc) nor animal products are used in the processing of the product. All the Santa Julia are bottled in our winery in Mendoza, Argentina."

Company email (September 2014)

"I am afraid to let you know that there are some wines that we have used products containing eggs to filter them, though this is a very expensive treatment. But because of this reason and because we are aware of vegan consumers we are starting to stop this use of products, as you may know some of our wines are from past vintages and have been already bottled so those are the wines my colleague Juan Ignacio was talking about. For  next vintages you will be able to try our wines because they will be with no traces of this kind of products!

Our Vegan Friendly Wines arriving into Dan Murphy’s by the end of this year:

Santa Julia Orgánico Malbec 2014
Santa Julia Orgánico Cabernet 2014
Santa Julia Orgánico Chardonnay 2014"

Note from David (April 2014):
"I noticed that Barnivore states that Santa Julia Wines is vegan friendly however on the label of a Santa Julia Syrah Rose bottle it says that it is produced with the aid of egg products. I've tried to contact the company directly but their website appears to be down. This is  the particular product I'm talking about if it helps https://www.danmurphys.com.au/product/DM_906226/santa-julia-syrah-ros"

Company email (January 2012):
"We don't use any ingredients of animal origin. Our products are produced just in our winery in Mendoza, Argentina"

Company email (February 2017):
"We don't use animal protein as fining agents in our Beaucastel wine "

Company email (July 2015):
"Our wines La Vieille ferme dont contain eggs, milk or honey. However we use animal products during in the processing of our wines La vieille Ferme.  Animal products are not present in the wine after filtration but we  prefer to say that our wines are not suitable for vegans"

Company email(November 2013):
"Our wines are not suitables for vegan."

Company email (January 2012):
"Nous avons une nouvelle contrainte aujourdhui en termes de produits oenologiques, la déclaration des allergènes majeurs lait et oeuf sur nos contre étqiuettes. Nous avons donc pris le parti pour nos  vins rouges de les coller avec de la gélatine de porc et de la bentonite quand cela est nécessaire. Sur nos vins issus de raisin de l'agriculture BIOLOGIQUE Perrin  Nature, nous essayons de ne pas les coller mais nous ne pouvons pas vous garantir qu'ils ne le soient jamais. Nous préférons donc  vous dire que ce vin ne convient ni  aux végétaliens, ni aux végétariens."

Google translation: "We have today a new constraint in terms of winemaking products, the declaration of major allergens milk and egg on our étqiuettes cons. We therefore decided to red wines to stick with pork gelatin and bentonite when necessary. About our wines from grapes of organic farming Perrin Nature, we try not to stick them but we can not guarantee they ever will be. We prefer to say that this wine is not suitable for vegans or vegetarians." [I think "stick" should actually be "fine".]
address: Château de Beaucastel, Chemin de Beaucastel

notes:
Company email (May 2012):
"I can confirm that First Cape full strength wines are Vegan friendly and are all made at the same facilities. Those of the 5.5% Discovery Range or the 4% Café Collection unfortunately are not."

Company email (March 2016):
"To your question about animal by-products in our product:  Our Henry of Pelham wines are Vegan Friendly. We also don’t use flour within the barrel walls."

Company email (January 2013):
"Unfortunately our wines do include animal products that are used in the filtration process."

Company email:
"We use 2 different products for our fining process.: isinglass (a fish product) and egg whites."

Company Email:

"Pillar Box Red is a vegan wine, as are all of our red wines.  Generally the only non vegan fining agent used on red wines is egg white, but we have not used this on any of the wines that are currently on the market.

We have however used gelatin and skim milk as fining agents on small parcels of our Pillar Box White, so this wine is obviously not a vegan wine. "

Company email (November 2014):
"The majority of our wines are fined with something, but we do have a few that are suitable for vegans. Obviously this changes from vintage to vintage and can't be counted on forever. But of our currently available wines the following are all vegan:

Innocent Bystander NV Prosecco
2012 Mule Viognier
2013 Mea Culpa Chardonnay
2013 Giant Steps Applejack Pinot Noir
2013 Mea Culpa Pinot Noir"

Company email (February 2014):
"Of our wines that are currently on release we only have a couple that are made without using animal products.
These are our 2012 Arthur’s Creek Chardonnay, and 2012 Gladysdale Pinot Noir."

From their blog (http://www.josefchromy.com.au/blog/vegan-friendly-wines, pulled Nov 4 2016):
"Over the past two years, Josef Chromy Wines have used a new means of clarifying some wines that involves a very small amount of gelatine (30-40 ppm), but yields massive savings in energy use. This means most of our aromatic whites are not vegan-friendly. Trials are underway with plant-derived gels instead of gelatine, but have been unsatisfactory so far.

Our Chardonnay doesn't go through this process, but in some years we use casein (milk product), and this rules out those particular vintages too.

Our Pinot Noirs - Pepik, Josef Chromy and Zdar - are vegan-friendly year in, year out.

The following current release wines ARE vegan-friendly: 

2015 Pepik Pinot Noir
2015 Josef Chromy Pinot Noir
2015 Josef Chromy Chardonnay
2015 Josef Chromy Fume Blanc
2010 Josef Chromy Vintage Sparkling
Josef Chromy Ruby Pinot (port)
2012 Zdar Chardonnay
2012 Zdar Pinot Noir
2005 Zdar Sparkling
2014 Josef Chromy Merlot"

Company email (February 2014):
"It is only on the Kadette range that we use some fining products, but the Pinotage, Cabernet Sauvignon and Paul Sauer are all suitable."

Company email (January 2016):
"All of our 2014 & 2015 vintages are vegan friendly as we do not use any animal byproducts for our wines."

Company email (June 2014):
"All of our current 2013 vintage wines do not contain any animal ingredients and are Vegan friendly :)"
Q: "Just a quick follow up question, would the 2012 and 2011 vintages be ok as well?  Or do you vary based on the year, etc...?"
A: "We have a new winemaker this year... He has assured me that his wines are all vegan friendly. I believe our other vintages are also fine but since that winemaker is not here anymore I cannot guarantee that they are vegan friendly."

Company email (February 2014):
"You’ll be glad to know that all of our reds at Langmeil are vegan friendly and we are trialling a potato derived protein on some whites which could replace gelatine as a juice fining agent. Unfortunately the milk products are harder to avoid for whites but we’re working on it."

Company email (April 2013):
"Some of our wines do contain milk &/ egg.

We make a number of wines that are suitable for Vegans- the Laissez Faire range. The wines in this range includes a Cabernet Sauvignon, a Syrah, a Grenache, a Fiano and a Riesling. These are all free of animal products."
address: T/A Australia West Wine Exports Pty Ltd., 15 York Street, Subiaco

notes:
Note from Markus on the translation (May 2013):
"ALL wines (reds and whites) use casein as part of the glue which sticks the wine label to the bottle. So basically the wine itself is translated right but the label on their bottles all use casein glue to be sticked onto the bottle except this one Cuveé which is 100% vegan friendly.
All others are actually not if you consider the bottling and labeling as being part of the "vegan" term."

Company email (May 2013):
"alle unsere Weiß- und Roseweine werden mit Gelatine geschönt, alle unsere Rotweine sind frei von tierischen Produkten als Hilfsstoff.

Milch, Ei, Honig usw ist in allen unseren Weinen nicht enthalten.

Alle unsere Etikettenleime enthalten Kasein.

Der Wein "Lenz Moser Carpe Diem Prestige Cuvee", erhältlich bei der Firma Hofer um € 9,99 je 0,75 l-Flasche ist eine Ausnahme: Dieser ist ein Rotwein und wurde nicht mit Gelatine geschönt und enthält anstelle eines Klebeetikettes eines Siebdruck."

[Google translation] "all our white and rose wines are fined with gelatin, all of our red wines are free of animal products as excipient.

Milk, egg, honey, etc are not included in all of our wines.

All our Etikettenleime contain casein.

The wine "Lenz Moser Prestige Cuvee Carpe Diem", available at the company Hofer at € 9.99 each 0.75 liter bottle is an exception: This is a red wine and was not fined with gelatin and contains an adhesive label instead of a screen."

Company email (January 2017)

"Many of our wines at Logan are vegan-friendly, however which exact wines are vegan-friendly will change from year to year. We like to be as organic as possible in the winery, which means that when we do use fining agents we will use eggs, milk or isinglass generally. Many of our wines do not require any fining and so these wines will be vegan-friendly, but as I said, the exact vegan-friendly wines will change from vintage to vintage."

Company email (December 2016)
"What I can say about our REDS wines (except BIO) is that we use gelatin from animal origins. For all the WHITES we don’t use any animal extracts, and they can be drunk by vegans."

Company email (January 2016):
"Ho il piacere di confermarle che nei nostri prodotti a marchio Mario Giacondi non viene utilizzato alcun tipo di ingrediente di derivazione animale. Sono quindi prodotti adatti al consumo vegano/vegetariano."

[Google Translation: "I am pleased to confirm that in our brand products Mario Giacondi not used any kind of animal-derived ingredient. Hence they are fit for consumption vegan / vegetarian"]

Company email (August 2015):
"we confirm that for our Giacondi wines we do not use any animal products or similar, just vegetal components."

Company email (March 2013):
"We received your e-mail about info on Nero d’Avola Giacondi. I can say that we use egg albumin and anything else referred to animals ingredients.
 
Our product is fully manufactured in Italy: the wine comes from Sicily and it is bottles in Piedmont where we have our main cellar.
Also, all the raw materials (labels/closure/carton……) are from Italy."

"We use only EGG ALBUMIN."

Company email:
"our Beaujolais wines are never fined, therefore they never contain egg traces, which is not the case for our Côte d'Or wines (fined with egg whites), there are therefore adapted to vegans."

Company email (March 2012):
"some of our wines are not fined and not filtered at all. And we use isinglass for fining some of our wines... Sauló 2010 wasn't fined at all."

Company Email:
"After checking with our team, I would like to confirm you that our white, rosé and sweet wines are "vega-friendly". This is not applicable to our red wines, that are clarified with a substance coming from fish-origin."

Company email (February 2016)

"Indeed, it was concerns similar to yours that we have been able to make subsequent vintages of our wines (since 2011) completely animal-product free.

"For fining, we now use Vegecol, a potato-based protein that is as efficient as albumin. You asked about the 2005, but all out wines from 2011 are suitable for vegans."

Company email (March 2014):
"I can confirm that All of the red wines are suitable for vegans UNLESS they say may contain traces of milk on the back label next to the sulphites.  All of the white wines are not as we use casein for fining and sometimes a little bit of the whites may cross over into the reds which is why that warning can sometimes come up on the label."

Company email (March 2017)
"unfortunately, we would not recommend our wines to vegans or/and vegetarians."

Company email (July 2016):
[same as December 2015]

Company email (December 2015):
"Our Technical Services Team advises that [Penfolds Cellar Reserve] in our current 2015 portfolio are vegan-friendly"

Company email (December 2013):
"We do not recommend any of our wine for vegans due to the possibility that the wine has been clarified with fining agents such as egg albumin, casein, gelatin and isinglass."

Company email (December 2012):
"It would depend on what type of vegetarian you are to determine if our wines are suitable for you, however we do not recommend any of our wine for vegans due to the possibility that the wine has been clarified with fining agents such as egg albumin, casein, gelatin and isinglass. 

Fining agents are used to reduce harsh tannin and remove several kinds of hazes that can be found in wine. In using these agents the winemaker is further fine-tuning the structure of the wine. The use of small amounts of fining agents is generally necessary to ensure that the wine will be clear, stable and sound, have longevity and be enjoyable to taste. 

The winemakers decide on which fining agents are used and these may vary from product to product and even batch to batch (usually depending on the grapes of that particular year). It is important to note that despite fining agents being used during the winemaking process, they are removed prior to bottling."

From a PDF with Rosemount, Penfolds and Lindemans logos on top:
We do not recommend any of our wine for vegans due to the possibility that the wine has been clarified with fining agents such as egg albumin, casein, gelatin and isinglass. The winemakers decide on which fining agents are used and these may vary from product to product and even batch to batch (usually depending on the grapes of that particular year).

Barnivore note (February 2014): Perrier-Jouët is owned by Pernod Ricard, a major funder of bullfighting.

Note from Danielle (February 2014): re: Grand Brut
"On the rear of the bottle it states: "This product may contain traces of the fining agent milk." I'll email the company for further information"

Company email (June 2013): [regarding Grand Brut]
"We thank you for your interest in our brand and for your enquiry. The answer to your question is YES !"

Company email (December 2011):
"I confirm to you that Perrier-Jouet Champagne is compatible with vegans"

Company email (April 2015):
"We traditionally do not use any animal products in the fining of our red wines, however in recent months due to the unprecedented sales of some of our wines, we have had to source wine and juice from some suppliers that have used milk products as a fining agent, whereas we traditionally do not use milk products for fining our Peter Lehmann red wines. 

We have been completely accurate in labelling the different batches of our wine and have declared when the milk product additive has been used in certain batches, but we have continued to label the batches that did not have the milk product added as a fining agent as 'Vegan Friendly'.

The milk product is used in very small quantities for fining and due to the way the proteins bind in the wine and the subsequent filtration process all trace amounts should be removed, however we still believe it is appropriate to declare whenever any additives that have the potential to be an allergen or impact on the philosophical choice of consumers for veganism have been used in the processing of the wine.

The good news is that from the 2014 vintage onwards the Vegan friendly declaration will once again appear on all of our Peter Lehmann red wines."

Company email (February 2014):
"Yes the ports are vegan and we already use cross flow filtration on all our wines."
Q: "Does that mean your white wines are now suitable for vegans too or do you still use lactic casein in addition to the filtration?"
A: "Correct casein is still added prior to filtration."

Company email (May 2013):
"All of our wines are made here at the winery in the Barossa Valley. Our red wines are not fined and contain no animal products but our white wines are fined with casein which is a milk derivative so therefore our red wines are fine for vegans and our white wines are fine for vegetarians."

Company email (February 2010):
"All Peter Lehmann red wines are suitable for vegans as we do not use fining agents. However, none of our white wines are suitable as these are fined with lactic casein which is a milk derivative."

Company email (February 2014):
"Louisa our winemaker, has just informed me that she has been making the wines deliberately vegan since 2008."

Note from Danielle (February 2014):
"I thought she meant that all vintages of the LBV and 40 YO Tawny were suitable, but she meant that all of the Vintages (Classic Fonseca Vintage, Fonseca Guimaraens and Fonseca Quinta do Panascal Single Quinta Vintage), and the LBV and 40YOT. I had been thinking that by vintages she was referring to years, as is the case with wines."

Company email (February 2014):
Q: "I'm a little confused as another person who contacted Fonseca was told that the vintage ports (Classic Fonseca Vintage, Fonseca Guimaraens and Fonseca Quinta do Panascal Single Quinta Vintage) were also suitable for vegans. Is this not the case? They were also told that the wines are not suitable as they're fined with gelatine but I was under the impression that all Fonseca wines were suitable. If you could help clear this up for me, I'd really appreciate it!"
A: "In my first email dated 16 July I wrote “Vegan Friendly Fonseca wines are all vintages, Fonseca unfiltered Late Bottled Vintage and Fonseca 40 year old tawny..” I do apologise for not having insisted that vintages are also suitable.
 
Not all Fonseca wines are suitable. Fonseca has a greater range of wines which are not suitable for vegans."

Company email (February 2014):
Q: "I just wanted to check whether the Fonseca LBV and Fonseca 40 Year Old Tawny were still the only vegan suitable ports available from Fonseca?"
A: "Yes this is still correct."

Company email (February 2014):
"Vegan Friendly Fonseca wines are all vintages, Fonseca unfiltered Late Bottled Vintage and Fonseca 40 year old tawny."

Company email (August 2012):
"The only products which are 100% suitable for vegans are all our Vintage Ports which include Classic Fonseca Vintage, Fonseca Guimaraens and Fonseca Quinta do Panascal Single Quinta Vintage. Our Late Bottled Vintage Port and 40 Year OId Aged Tawny Port are also suitable.

All other Fonseca wines include products that are not suitable for vegetarians, such as gelatin."

Company email (January 2016):
"The only ingredients in the majority of our wines are Grapes and Yeast. Sulfur is added during the crushing to control micro-organisms. The exception is our sparkling wines to which we add standard white sugar to start a secondary fermentation.
We use Diatomaceous clay as a fining agent on all of our wines."

[Given the difference in answers, we're assuming a production change between 2012 and 2016]

Company email (October 2012):
"For clarification purposes only, we use casein (milk protein) on our wines."

Company email (January 2017)
"We do produce some vegan friendly wines, mainly Sauvignon Blanc’s.

Currently we have the following vegan friendly wines open on tasting;

Traditional Methode Sparkling Wine DAWN 2012
Wairau Reserve Sauvignon Blanc 2016
Godfreys Creek Reserve Pinot Gris 2016
Premium Sauvignon Blanc 2016

All those wine haven’t been filtered with any kind of animal product"

Company email (November 2011)

All of our sauvignon blancs are vegan every year. If we do need to fine our
sauvignon blancs which is necessary every three years or so then we will use
a vegan friendly product.

Unfortunately there is no hard and fast rule for the other varieties we
make. Every year different levels of bitterness are produced in the grape
skins and different treatments are used to make the best wine we can. 

As 2011 was a high phenolic (bitter) year the only other white wine we
produced without the use of milk products is Pioneer Block 9 Riesling 2011.

Company email (May 2014):
"Please find attached a list of our wines - unless marked on the attached list, & the additive listed next to it, the wine is vegan friendly." [Please email contact@barnivore.com if you would like a copy of the .pdf list."

Company email (April 2013):
"We have only 1 wine that was fined with an animal ingredient. The 2012 Estate Reserve Chardonnay with skim milk powder.
Apart from this one, none of the wines were produced with either an animal ingredient or product."

Company email (February 2013):
"If you are looking for a vegan-friendly Port you can choice the Sandeman Vintage (all vintage crops) and Sandeman LBV.

All the other range is treated (fined) with gelatin from animal origin. Hope in the future we can use only vegetal gelatin.

Sandeman Ports are exclusively produced and bottled in Portugal."

Company email (December 2012):
"My red wines have no animal products used in their making and have no fining or filtration. So would be ok for vegans.

The pressings components  (about 10%) of each of my white wines all have had a gelatin fining and then once settled are returned to the free run juice, and in 2012 my La Prova Pinot Grigio and La Prova Sparkling Pinot Grigio had some casein (milk) fining, so are probably not suitable for vegans.

Ngeringa and Protero, great Adelaide Hills wineries, Kalleske in the Barossa or Battle of Bosworth in McLaren Vale would be good wines to track down, and may have something white to suit."

Company email (February 2014):
"The 2012 Cabernet contains no additives that are unsuitable for vegan consumption.
The only additive that we occasionally use is egg whites and they are used in very small amounts to fine out hard tannins in red wines. These are then filtered out but we still put on the label “may contain egg product” to account for any residue.
 
We do not Isinglass or Gelatine to fine our wines."

Company email (April 2012):
"The 2009 MOMO Pinot Noir is vegan-friendly – it contains no animal products. There are no other places where our MOMO Wines are made other than right here in Marlborough, so this will be true of all the 2009 MOMO Pinot Noir.
 
The only animal product we use for some wines in some vintages is Gelatine, but none of this was used in the 2009 MOMO Pinot Noir.
 
The 2011 MOMO Chardonnay, 2011 MOMO Pinot Gris, 2009 MOMO Riesling are also vegan friendly. The 2010 MOMO Sauvignon Blanc used gelatine, but the certified organic 2011 MOMO Sauvignon which we will release shortly did not."

540001.Metode: Skånsom pressing av druene, gjæret i sement- og ståltanker samt eldre eikefat, 14 dagers maserasjon, 8 md. flaskemodning etter malolaktisk gjæring.
540001.Lukt: Aroma preget av modne mørke bær, urter og lakris, hint av fat og kokos.
540001.Smak: Bløt og rik stil, preg av mørke bær, urter, lakris og fat, litt varm ettersmak.

notes:
Jayne notes (November 2016):
"2014 passion for red lips by some young punks now contains milk...  it states it on the bottle."

Company email (February 2014):
"all reds are suitable for vegans, white aren't (all are fined with milk products). So you're good to go with any of the red wines."

Company email (December 2011)
"Most of our reds are vegan friendly, all the whites unfortunately are out of the question. Available at the moment suitable are the following:
'10 Lust Collides
'10 Fierce Allure
'10 Double Love Trouble
'10 Passion has Red Lip"

Note: Cockburn's is owned by Pernod Ricard, a major funder of bullfighting.

Company email (December 2015):

"Regarding your question about the Port wines suitable for a Vegan diet we are pleased to introduce you to a portfolio of wines suitable for consumption by Vegans and Vegetarians, whose price quality ratio is very satisfactory and that You will surely appreciate.

"You can try and appreciate:

* Vintage Ports from all our brands: Graham’s, Dow’s, Cockburn’s, Warre’s, Smith Woodhouse and Quinta do Vesúvio
* Single Quinta Vintage Ports
** Graham’s - Quinta dos Malvedos
** Dow’s - Quinta da Senhora da Ribeira and Quinta do Bomfim
** Warre’s - Quinta da Cavadinha
** Cockburn’s - Quinta dos Canais
** Smith Woodhouse - Madalena
* Crusted Ports – Graham’s and Dow’s
* Warre’s and Smith Woodhouse – Bottled Matured LBV Port (Late Bottled Vintage Port)"

Company email (October 2015):
"...we are pleased to inform you that, except Bottled Matured Ports, namely Vintage Ports, Single Quinta Vintage Ports and crusted Ports, Port wines may be fined with Pork Gelatin and Bentonite. Graham’s Six Grapes Reserve Port may be fined with Pork Gelatin and Bentonite."

Company email (August 2015):
"In response to your query, two of Cockburn’s Ports, Cockburn’s Vintage Port and Cockburn’s Quinta dos Canais Single Quinta Vintage Port are suitable for vegans. All other styles of Cockburn’s Port (ruby, tawny, white, LBV and Special Reserve) could potentially contain traces of products unsuitable for vegans."

Company email (April 2013):
"Regarding your question we would like to inform that during the production of Dows Fine Ruby Port more precisely at the fining step it is only used Gelatine from porcine origin. Please note that  this is not an ingredient but a processing aid. No other product from animal source is used."

Company email (December 2011):
"In fact, some of the premium Ports (modern LBV, Reserves, Aged Tawnies) are fined with egg components. Those are suitable for vegetarians but not for vegans.

Almost all the standard Ports are fined with animal products (Ruby, Tawny, White).

Anyway, you can enjoy all the Bottle Matured Ports, those are not fined, clarified or filtered:

Vintage Port
Quinta Vintage Port
Bottle Aged Late Bottled Vintage (also designated as Bottle Matured Late Bottled Vintage)

Examples of very good Ports you can drink:
Dow’s Vintage Port
Warre’s Vintage Port
Cockburn’s Vintage Port
Graham’s Vintage Port
Dow’s Quinta do Bomfim Vintage Port
Warre’s Quinta da Cavadinha Vintage Port
Cockburn’s Quinta dos Canais Vintage Port
Graham’s Quinta dos Malvedos Vintage Port
Warre’s Bottle Aged LBV
Smith Woodhouse Bottle Matured LBV

Company email (September 2016) regarding Viogneir:

"Yes suitable for vegans"

Company email (December 2016):
"Due to the filtration process used, Taylor’s [First Estate Reserve Port] is not suitable for vegetarians. However, the following Taylor’s Port are suitable:

Taylor’s Late Bottled Vintage
Taylor’s 30 Year Old
Taylor’s 40 Year Old
All Vintage Ports
All Single Quinta Ports"

Company email (March 2015):
"The following Taylor’s Ports are suitable for vegetarians and vegans:
Taylor’s Late Bottled Vintage
Taylor’s 30 Year Old
Taylor’s 40 Year Old
All Vintage Ports
All Single Quinta Ports"

Company email (January 2013):
"All of our Vintage Ports and Single Quinta Vintage Ports are suitable for vegans and vegetarians.
Our Port is only produced by us, in Portugal."

Company email (January 2017)

"I’d love to have a clear answer for you however whether our wines are vegan or vegetarian can change vintage to vintage, depending on the type of tannins or phenolics in the grape and wine that year. Each vintage produces grapes with different levels of these each year and depending on these levels (high rain vs high sun etc) we sometimes need to add fining agents which may consist of non-vegetarian or vegan ingredients.

"Where possible we try not to use animal derived fining agents, however in some instances it is only an animal protein that will address the particular phenolic in the wine. In future vintages we plan to indicate on the back label if the wine is vegan or vegetarian friendly.

"In general, all red wines will be lightly fined with fresh egg whites due to the higher tannic content as a results of fermenting on skins. In comparison, Sauvignon Blanc will have no animal fining. Fresh skim milk is sometimes required for Chardonnay due to its interaction with oak which also delivers tannin of a different form.

"Again my apologies for such a convoluted answer. For all 2017 vintage wines we aim to have this stated on the label as well as tasting notes for each wine which will be easily referenced and downloaded via our website."

Company email (August 2016)

"Most of our wines are vegan suitable, with very few exceptions.  Currently, the only two wines which aren’t vegan are The Drama Queen sparkling and Agent Provocateur red blend."

Company email (June 2011):

"Unfortunately we are not vegan friendly as we do use gelatin and isinglass in our wines, except in the Longmarket Pinot Grigio which Woolworths buy from us for their stores."

Company email (September 2016)

"I can confirm that all of our red wines (Tempranillo, Sangiovese, GSM and Shiraz) are all vegan friendly as we do not use any fining agents."

Company email (May 2013):
"Our products are all manufactured on site. The only product that had animal products used in processing is the Merlot (4 egg whites as fining). All other products can be considered vegan. Fining (when used) is performed with bentonite clay. Sugar can be used in the processing of some wines. Potassium metabisulphite is used as a preservative and anti-oxidant. That pretty much my toolkit (besides yeast and yeast nutrient, again not animal based."

Company email (December 2016):
"Of my current releases, the below are vegan-friendly wines.   Please note we do make wines with skim milk and free-range eggs in the same winery.

Jen Pfeiffer The Hero Pinot Grigio 2016
Jen Pfeiffer The Diamond Tawny NV
Jen Pfeiffer The Diamond Muscat NV"

Company email (April 2013):
"Yes, I do make vegan friendly wines.
 
The following wines are vegan friendly:
Pfeiffer Riesling
Pfeiffer Moscato
Pfeiffer Frontignac
Pfeiffer Seriously Pink
Pfeiffer Christopher's VP
 
All these wines are made on site by myself, so I can say with real assurance that these wines are 100% vegan friendly.
 
I am also researching other fining agents (man-made) to replace some of the traditional protein fining agents (such as milk and egg) to make more of my wines suitable for vegans...watch this space!"

Company email (July 2012):
"Although they don't have an allergen statement on the label, most of our fortified wines are fined with a gelatin based fining agent, which thus makes them inappropriate for vegan consumption. 
 
However, our 2008 Pfeiffer Christopher's VP (most likely released towards the end of the year) has not been fined with any animal products at all.
 
The other products that we make without any animal products are the 2012 Pfeiffer Riesling, the 2011 Pfeiffer Frontignac and the 2012 Pfeiffer Moscato."

Editor's note: 
Email sent for clarification February 2010.

Company Email about all labels:
"My original answer does apply to all of them yes, although with the Radford
Dale and Black Rock wines, we tend to intervene as little as possible and
generally avoid fining of these reds."
 
Company Email:
"The Vinum Africa Cab ’06 is Vegan-friendly…! "

Company Email about Vinum:
"We do sometimes use isinglass for our white wines to facilitate the flocculation of Bentonite when protein stabilising. For our reds, we sometimes have used a gelatine based fining agent in the past, but evaluate each wine on its own merits and thus some wines will not contain any such animal derived substances. "

Company email (August 2016)

"Cette question est vraiment très complexe pour les vins en général. Nous ne souhaitons pas figurer dans votre annuaire étant donné que cela nécessite beaucoup d’explications et de précisions techniques."

[Translation: "This question is very complex for wines in general. We do not want included in your directory since it requires a lot of explanations and technical details."]

Hayden notes (November 2015) that the 2013 Galway Shiraz says vegan on the label.

Company email (February 2014): re: Museum Antique Tawny
"Unfortunately, since your last inquiry three years ago, our fortified wines have not yet reached vegan status, the current batches on the market still contain a small amount of gelatine. Although probably of little consolation, the residual amount is very small and still exceeds the reportable level of 2 mg/L, that is, 4 mg/L in our Antique Tawny and 8 mg/L in our Museum Muscat.

Although we ceased using animal products in our fortifieds in 2010, the nature of our production involves considerable backlog of stock, meaning it will be sometime before these wines reach a level that can be declared vegan-friendly - I'm sorry to say this will possibly take a further 2-3 years for our Antique Tawny and 4-5 years for our Museum Muscat.

Once they do become vegan/vegetarian-friendly, we will be including in our list of wines."

Note from Michelle (January 2013):
"I have discovered Yalumba wineries who make a large range of fabulous vegan wines." [PDF included showing vintages through 2011. Please contact them for a copy of the PDF file.}

From the company, January 2012:
"From 2011, all Yalumba and Hill-Smith Family Vineyard wines have been produced as vegan and vegetarian friendly. [PDF also included of past vintages]"

Editor's note: They sent a detailed PDF of all their vegan wines dated December 2010. Please contact them for your copy of the PDF. 

Company email:
"Thank you for taking the time to visit our website and enquire about our wines. We have several wines that are vegan-friendly and do not use any animal-derived fining agents, I have attached our list for you. Please note that not all vintages of the same wine are suitable for vegans (only the ones listed) and some of the older vintages may no longer be available in the stores. A few of these may not be available in the US.

The entire Oxford Landing range is now vegan-friendly as well as all of our Yalumba 2 litre red wine casks. Also, the entire Yalumba Y Series range starting from 2010 vintage is vegan (some Y Series wines from previous vintages were also vegan, you will see them on the list)."

Company email (June 2010):
"...I managed to obtain the Yalumba list of vegetarian- and vegan-friendly wines. See attached PDF"

Company email (June 2016):
"I have re-checked with our winemaking team and all of our wines are vegan friendly from 2014 vintage onwards (except for the Peter Yealands Merlot 2014).  Some of our older reds (2013 vintages) were fined with egg whites.

"We use a potato fining and NO animal products.  If you look at our tasting notes on our website they will say vegan friendly.  There is a view to add this information to back labels from 2016 vintages."

Company email (December 2015):
"All of our wines from, and including 2014 are vegan friendly. We did use to use egg whites on the Pinot Noir from our own free range chickens on the property but stopped doing that in 2013."

Update December 2015: Despite the answers below, there's evidence online that at least the Yealands Pinot Noir undergoes fining with eggs. We've changed that one to not vegan, and are waiting for confirmation on the others - JD

Company email (February 2015):
"The majority of our wines are suitable for vegans.   Our Peter Yealands Sauvignon Blanc, Riesling, Pinot Noir & new aromatic blend of P.G.R are all suitable."

Company email (December 2014): re: Riesling
"Yes absolutely it is."

Company email (December 2014):
"All of our Sauvignon Blanc is suitable for Vegan and Vegetarian, which is something that I feel strongly about :). It is all made here in Marlborough."
address: Corner of Seaview and Reserve Roads, PO Box 545 Blenheim

notes:
Company email (February 2014):
"I have some very good news for you – our red wines are vegan friendly, with no fining or filtration."

Company email (February 2012):
"Reds are vegan friendly, most whites are too. Occasionally with the whites we may fine with skimmed milk powder or isinglass.  As a winery, all wines are made here."
